awd_titl_txt: GOALI/CPS:Medium:A Framework for Enabling Energy-Aware Smart Facilities
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of the proposed research is to identify ways to inexpensively provide specific information about energy consumption in buildings and facilitate conservation. Signal processing, machine learning, and data fusion techniques will be developed to extract actionable information from whole-building power meters and other available sensors. The main objectives are: (a) to create a framework for obtaining disaggregated, appliance-specific feedback about electricity consumption in a building by extracting high-value information from low-cost data sources; and (b) to investigate and develop data mining and machine learning algorithms for making use of appliance-specific electricity data, in order to provide users with recommendations on how to optimize their energy consumption and understand the effects of their energy-related decisions. A series of residential buildings in Pittsburgh, PA will serve as a test-bed for evaluating and validating our proposed approach. Blueroof Technologies, a non-profit corporation located in McKeesport, PA that researches, develops and provides affordable senior-citizen housing with integrated sensor networks and building automation systems, will provide access to their Research Cottages for this project. Similarly, Robert Bosch LLC, a leading global provider of consumer goods and building technology, will provide additional technical research assistance and expertise.

The main scientific merit of the project is the development of a framework for evaluating energy-use-disaggregation methods according to their value for promoting energy conservation. The resulting data sets will be large enough to produce significant conclusions about the feasibility and effectiveness of the technology, and allow for the development of new models about the trends and patterns of appliance usage in buildings. 

Broader impacts of this research include providing a foundation for future cyber-physical systems by inexpensively obtaining real-time appliance-level data. Such data can be used to help reduce the energy consumption of buildings by revealing the relationship between users' behavior and electricity consumption in buildings. The proposed industry-university collaborative research effort with Bosch will ensure that the technology and scientific contributions are steered toward innovative solutions that are practical for adoption in the market. Furthermore, the project will have significant diversity contributions by attracting minority students through collaboration with the University of Maryland Eastern Shore, a land-grant, historically black college with a diverse student body. Finally, a series of planned industry seminars, workshops and the publication of journal articles will allow  further dissemination of the work.

The goal of this research project was to study ways to inexpensively monitor the energy consumed by electrical loads in residential buildings (e.g., appliances). By relying on aggregate data (i.e., measurements of overall power consumption reported monthly), homeowners and facility managers are currently blind to the contribution of individual appliances and activities to the overall energy consumed. And while there is adequate evidence suggesting that providing real-time, appliance-specific data allows users to achieve significant energy savings, the available solutions in the market are either inadequately granular or prohibitively expensive.

Our team first analyzed the results of appliance penetration surveys, to determine the top consumers in households across the U.S. and to better charactherize the requirements for the monitoring solution we were interested in. We then designed, implemented and tested computer algorithms and systems to extract appliance-level information from measurements of the total electricity consumed in a household. This approach has the advantage of minimizing the hardware costs (just one sensor system per household) and could later be scaled across the nation by embedding the final solution into the metering infrastructure that electric utilities have in place. In the academic community, this approach is known as Non-Intrusive Load Monitoring (NILM).

As a result of our efforts, we produced significant contributions to the body of knowledge around NILM. For example, the team contributed novel algorithms for detecting significant changes in the total power measurements from a house, which could be attribtued to a change in operational state of individual appliances. These algorithms were disseminated through publications and talks around the world.

Similarly, our group was the first to publish a high-resolution dataset of power measurements for a single home, along with manual annotations of all the significant appliance switching events that occurred over a period of 7 days. This now publicly available dataset can be used by other researchers aroudn the world to test their own algorithms and compare the results in a standarized way.

Because this class of NILM algorithms need to be trained (or calibrated), our group also studied ways to facilitate the training process. Typcially, a human would have to assist by indicating which appliance was responsible for each one of the events that occur during the training period. Our team investigated ways to reduce this effort by grouping together appliance events that were similar in nature, and only eliciting feedback from humans once enough information about them has been captured. These techniques were documented and tested, and the results were disseminated in academic venues.

Based on the above findings, we then developed and tested an end-to-end NILM solution which, in addition to including our solutions to the event detection and training problems, included novel algorithms for extracting useful features out of the measurements (e.g., what can be referred to as a fingerprint for each appliance) and algorithms for estimating the energy consumed by each of these appliances. The results of our pilots studies with a prototye of the system showed that the system could track the energy consumed by individual appliances in the households with an average accuracy of approximately 80%, though this number varied significantly across different classes of appliances.
